ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Learned how to analyze analog circuits in the time and frequency domains as well as switching between the two.
A much better understanding of complex circuits and circuit analysis techniques.
I learned basics of signals and their applications in the frequency domain. I learned Laplace and Fourier transforms
We learned more about circuits, frequency analysis, and fourier and laplace transforms.

This course deals with linear circuits. Important base knowledge for all electrical engineers, but not super relevant to most modern day applicationsunless you're going to be a circuit designer. It does introduce many analysis techniques that are relevant to many other fieldsincluding fourier, laplace, state space analysis.
I learned about frequency domain in circuit analysis and how techniques like Laplace and Fourier transform allow circuits with arbitrary signals to be solved.
I learned how to design circuits effectively, I learned foundations for differential equations, and ways to solve them and apply to circuits.
Circuit laws, time domain analysis, frequency domain analysis, applications to circuit design

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Professor had a great understanding of the material. The homework was a little too challenging, and sometimes the homework problems covered topics not discussed in class. The labs were fun and very educational.
The course is well taught. The homework generally correlates well with what we've been doing in class, but is sometimes a bit harder than the contents of the lectures which can be difficult.

strengths:
- very organized
- good material
- professor is great
- homeworks were extremely fair; you learned material and they were not that long
- exams were amazing, hard and challenging but also short; that is to say, they really tested concept understanding

weaknesses:
- ta's were not present
- ta's did not host office hours
- ta's were not friendly
The course had labs that often felt like busy worm and did not allow us to truly understand what we were doing

Professor Tang made us submit our homeworks on paper, not through canvas which was very frustrating. The labs were incredibly confusing and poorly designed. Many key instructions necessary for the lab were never mentioned anywhere in the lab notes, which greatly increased time spent in the lab and led to a very confused group of students. The exams were reasonably difficult, and the workload was never excessive. We weren't allowed to use the real oscilloscopes, and instead had to use a module provided to us. I feel like it would have been more beneficial to let us use the real oscilloscopes. 8 labs that all take 3 hours is a lot, especially because it doesn't count as an extra half credit. TAs were not very helpful. Sunny was not a good TA, very condescending and rude. Office hours were held at inconvenient times for most students.
Material is great. Lectures sometimes unclear

Strengths: the order is logical, problems are very relevant to exams and highlight key concepts, lectures and lecture notes very thorough

Weaknesses: we did not really discuss any elements like op amps or transistors in detail. Also we had no circuit design component even though this course had a lab (every lab was very similar).

Strengths: How everything applies in the real world
Weakness: Not enough practice on foundations of diff eq or how to solve effectively.

Strengths: Professor Tang is a really great lecturer, course content was well designed, labs were manageable
Weaknesses: None

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, it's requires but also analog circuits are interesting and math is fun. If you disagree with both those things, that's unfortunate.
Yes, if you're interested in circuits or a major that requires this course. It's a good course but probably boring for someone not especially interested.
I would recommend this course to a student in engineering because it allows them to have hands on experience in a lab setting

Not really. You'll learn some useful things about circuits, but this class is much more difficult than it needs to be. Hong is fine as a lecturer, he explains things clearly enough, but almost everything else about this course is just inconvenient. Having to submit homework on paper instead of digitally because "If you submit through canvas, I won't be able to give you any feedback" was really annoying and just untrue, To Hong's credit, our homeworks were always graded in a week, and the midterm grades came back pretty fast too. Labs desperately need reorganized. Many of them are monotonous and I didn't get much out of them. This class would be much better if they just reworked it.

Required for all EE/EECS. It's basically Circuits IIyou've learned ohms law and some basic techniques in EENG 202now you get expanded to all linear circuits (resistors, capacitors, inductors). Not incredibly enlightening, but important for any electrical engineer. Not the best course in the major, but does a good job providing an applied overview of linear systems analysis (diff eq, fourier, laplace, state space, etc.)which are all helpful in almost any engineering field.
Yes, because the frequency domain is essential for anyone interested in electrical engineering.
Yes, if you want to design circuits.
Yes
